problem_text:
∗18.89. Consider the set of balanced presentations ⟨x1, . . . , xn | r1, . . . , rn⟩ with fixed n generators x1, . . . , xn. By definition, the group ACn of Andrews–Curtis moves on this set of balanced presentations is generated by the Nielsen transformations together with conjugations of relators. Is ACn finitely presented?
J. Swan, A. Lisitsa
∗The group AC2 is not finitely presented (S. Krsti´c, J. McCool, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 56, no. 2 (1997), 264–274; also V. A. Roman’kov, Preprint, 2023, https://arxiv.org/pdf/2305.11838.pdf), while the groups ACn, n ⩾ 3, are finitely presented, which follows from (G. Kiralis, S. Krstiˇc, J. McCool, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 73, no. 3 (1996), 481–720).
(M. Ershov, Letter of 16 October 2025, https://kourovkanotebookorg.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/kourovka1889.pdf).
answer: The group AC2 is not finitely presented (S. Krsti´c, J. McCool, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 56, no. 2 (1997), 264–274; also V. A. Roman’kov, Preprint, 2023, https://arxiv.org/pdf/2305.11838.pdf), while the groups ACn, n ⩾ 3, are finitely presented, which follows from (G. Kiralis, S. Krstiˇc, J. McCool, Proc. London Math. Soc. (3), 73, no. 3 (1996), 481–720). (M. Ershov, Letter of 16 October 2025, https://kourovkanotebookorg.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/kourovka1889.pdf).
